   Additional multifocal peribronchial opacities bilaterally suggest

   Assessment and Plan:  83M with sCHF (EF 40%), presenting from OSH with
   acute hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP, unexplained
   hemoptysis and acute on CKI.
   .
   # Acute Hypoxemic Respitatory Failure: The patient presented from an
   OSH with with vent setting of 10 PEEP, 40% Fi02. Last p02 of 60 on
   FiO2, PEEP 10.  Increased FiO2 to 50%.  Differential of failure
   includes BOOP, CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis e.g. Goodpasture's
   syndrome, and VAP.  No evidence of emphasematous changes on recent
   imaging to suggest obstructive physiology.
   - will upload outside hospital imaging
   - will wean steroids
   - will convert to meropenem for Klebsiella in sputum, repeat sputum cx,
   follow up sensitivies
   - see below for CHF management
   .
   # Question BOOP/COP: Patient with symptoms of dyspnea, hemoptysis.
   Evidence on CT noted above in history. Autoantibodies such as [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA
   were noted to be negative.  Path report c/w BOOP.  The patient is now
   s/p  days of 0.5 gm of Solumedrol. Patients last PFTs were noted to be
   consistent with mild to moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.
   - Upload CT Chest into records -> f/u in PACS
   - attempt to obtain path slide for additional review
   - begin steroid wean to once daily methylprednisolone
   - will repeat ANCA, [**Doctor First Name **], anti-GBM
   .
   #. Chronic Systolic CHF: Pt with last known EF of 40%. Now appears to
   be clinically hypervolemic with likely intravascular depletion.
   Diuresis unsuccessful yesterday, per report, now appears to be
   improving according to physician at OSH.
   - repeat TTE this morning
   - will place on lasix gtt this morning, goal (-) 2 to 2.5 liters today
   - favor optimizing CHF regimen with afterload reduction -> will start
   isosorbide mononitrate, avoid ACEi given tenuous renal fxn, B blockade
   given 1^st degree AV block
   .
   # CAD s/p angioplasty, stent x 1:  troponin elevated, CK and MB
   normal.  Given recent history of hemoptysis and possible RML
   hemorrhage, renal insufficiency, and no significant ECG changes from
   admission to OSH, will defer anti-platelet and anti-coagulation at this
   time.  Will continue to trend and continue ASA 325 mg daily
   - hold statin in setting of transaminitis
   .
   #. Acute on Chronic Kidney Injury: DDx includes prerenal azotemia (poor
   forward flow, intravascular depletion), intrinsic, post-renal. Although
   now with signs of fluid overload, BUN of 200.  No signs of acidosis,
   hyperkalemia to sugest urgent emergeny need for dialysis. Pt may
   require HD vs CVVH given azotemia.  Steroid-induced catabolic state
   likely etiology of elevated BUN.
   - Avoid Nephrotoxins
   - UA with sediment and cx
   - Urine Lytes
   - f/u Renal recs, appreciate recs
   .
   #.  Hypernatremia- suspect intravascular volume depletion in setting of
   recent diuresis and elevated BUN, serum osmolality.
   -  will correct free water deficit with D5W, 1.7 liters to correct to
   148 in next 8 hours
   -  serial Na
   .
   #.  Type II DM- on SSI, consider insulin gtt in morning.
   .
   FEN: no IVF
   .
   PPX:
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboots
   -Bowel regimen
   -Pain management
   .
   ACCESS: PIV, right PICC
   .
   Full Code
   .

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure (CHF), chronic kidney injury (CKI), and coronary artery disease (CAD) who presented to the ICU with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient's current condition and potential medical complications are as follows:

1. Acute Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure: The patient presented with severe respiratory distress requiring invasive ventilation. The differential diagnosis includes bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP), CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis (e.g., Goodpasture's syndrome), and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient's recent imaging does not show any evidence of obstructive physiology.

2. BOOP/COP: The patient has symptoms of dyspnea and hemoptysis, along with evidence of BOOP on CT imaging. Autoantibodies such as ANCA were negative, and the pathology report confirmed BOOP. The patient received 0.5 gm of Solumedrol for treatment and is currently undergoing steroid weaning.

3. Chronic Systolic CHF: The patient has a known ejection fraction (EF) of 40%. He appears to be clinically hypervolemic with likely intravascular depletion. Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of chronic systolic heart failure (EF 40%), presenting from an outside hospital (OSH) with acute hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient has evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP), unexplained hemoptysis, and acute on chronic kidney injury. The patient underwent angioplasty and stenting for coronary artery disease but has elevated troponin levels. The patient also has hypernatremia, type II diabetes mellitus, and is suspected to have MRSA infection.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure: The patient presented with respiratory failure and requires invasive ventilation. The differential diagnosis includes BOOP, congestive heart failure (CHF), ANCA-associated vasculitis, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
2. Chronic Systolic CHF: The patient has a known ejection fraction of 40% and appears to be clinically hypervolemic with likely intravascular depletion. Optimizing CHF regimen with afterload reduction is recommended.
3. Acute on Chronic Kidney Injury: The patient has an elevated BUN of 200, and the differential diagnosis includes prerenal azotemia, intrinsic renal injury, and post-renal obstruction. Renal function tests and imaging should be followed up.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, and correction of free water

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of chronic systolic CHF, presenting from an outside hospital with acute hypoemic respiratory failure. He has evidence of bilateral pleural effusions with compressive atelectasis, multifocal peribronchial opacities suggesting infection, and moderate emphysema at the lung apices. The patient is currently intubated and sedated, requiring invasive ventilation. He has a Foley catheter in place, and his urine output has been noted to be low. The patient's sodium level is elevated, indicating hypernatremia. His renal function is impaired, with elevated BUN and creatinine levels. He also has an elevated troponin level, suggesting possible myocardial injury or ischemia. The patient's current medical conditions include acute respiratory failure (not ARDS), severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, altered mental status (not delirium), and chronic kidney injury.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the prolonged mechanical ventilation, there is an increased risk of developing VAP.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Immobility and the presence of central venous catheters increase the risk of developing DVT.
3. Stress ulcers: Critical illness and the use of corticosteroids can increase the risk of stress ulcers in the gastrointestinal tract.
4. Renal failure: The patient's impaired renal function may wors

   Assessment and Plan:  83M with systolic heart failure, presenting from
   OSH with acute hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP and
   acute on CKI.
   .
   # Acute Hypoxemic Respitatory Failure: The patient presented from an
   OSH with with vent setting of 10 PEEP, 40% Fi02. Last p02 of 60 on
   FiO2, PEEP 10.  Increased FiO2 to 50%.  Differential of failure
   includes CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis e.g. Goodpasture's syndrome,
   VAP, and obstructive lung disease (noted on CT chest from OSH).
   Patients last PFTs were noted to be consistent with mild to moderate
   restrictive ventilatory defect.  Autoantibodies such as [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA were
   noted to be negative.  Path report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside
   hospital shows clear RML hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Systolic heart
   failure, as evidence by TTE, likely primary component.
   - son to attempt to obtain non-cont CT chest done prior to [**2139-1-5**]
   bronch
   - will cont to wean methylpred to 40 mg daily tomorrow
   - BAL today
   - f/u repeat vasculitis serologies
   - Klebsiella resistant only to amp, will convert [**Last Name (un) 614**] to cipro
   - see below for CHF management
   - attempt to obtain path slide for additional review
   .
   #. Chronic Systolic CHF: Pt with last known EF of 40%. TTE shows slight
   decline in systolic function with clear volume overload. Now appears to
   be clinically hypervolemic.
   - cont lasix gtt this morning, goal (-) 2 to 4 liters today
   - cont afterload reduction with isosorbide, avoiding ACEi given renal
   fxn, avoiding B blockade given 1^st degree heart block
   .
   # CAD s/p angioplasty, stent x 1:  troponin elevated, CK and MB
   normal.  Given recent history of hemoptysis and possible RML
   hemorrhage, renal insufficiency, and no significant ECG changes from
   admission to OSH, will defer anti-platelet and anti-coagulation at this
   time.  Will continue to trend and continue ASA 325 mg daily.  Repeat
   ECG unchanged yesterday.
   - hold statin in setting of transaminitis
   - troponin stable, will stop trending
   .
   #. Acute on Chronic Kidney Injury: DDx includes prerenal azotemia (poor
   forward flow, intravascular depletion), intrinsic. Although now with
   signs of fluid overload, BUN of 200.  No signs of acidosis,
   hyperkalemia to sugest urgent emergeny need for dialysis. Pt may
   require HD vs CVVH given azotemia.  Steroid-induced catabolic state
   likely etiology of elevated BUN.  Creatinine stable at 2 and unchanged
   from [**2139-1-5**].
   - Avoid Nephrotoxins
   - UA with sediment and cx
   - Urine Lytes
   - f/u Renal recs, appreciate recs, cont with diuresis
   .
   #.  Hypernatremia- free water deficit likely [**2-10**] mechanical
   ventilation.
   -  will correct free water deficit with D5W
   -  serial Na
   .
   # Altered Mental Status- Patient has not been alert/interactive since
   transfer.  Sedation held for period of time yesterday, without
   improvement.  No clonus on exam, although significant uremia likely
   contributing to altered mental status.
   - will attempt daily awakenings, wean sedation
   .
   #.  Type II DM- convert to insulin gtt.
   .
   FEN: no IVF/replete lytes/TFs for nutrition
   .

   -Bowel regimen
   -Pain management

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, presenting from an outside hospital with acute hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient has evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) and acute on chronic kidney injury. The patient's last known ejection fraction (EF) was 40%, and a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) shows a slight decline in systolic function with clear volume overload. The patient has been sedated and intubated since transfer. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure: The patient presented with respiratory failure, which can be caused by various factors such as congestive heart failure (CHF), ANCA-associated vasculitis (e.g., Goodpasture's syndrome), ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), or obstructive lung disease. The patient's imaging from outside the hospital shows a clear right middle lobe (RML) hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy. Systolic heart failure is likely the primary component.

2. Chronic Systolic CHF: The patient has a history of CHF with a last known EF of 40%. The TTE shows a slight decline in systolic function with clear volume overload. The patient appears to be clinically hypervolemic.

3. Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) post angioplasty and stent: The patient had elevated troponin levels

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C (99.8°F), a heart rate of 91 beats per minute, blood pressure of 171/75 mmHg, respiratory rate of 31 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to a combination of factors including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), pulmonary edema, and bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP). Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 83-year-old male with multiple comorbidities including systolic heart failure, chronic kidney disease, diabetes mellitus type II, peripheral vascular disease, and altered mental status. The patient is currently in the ICU for acute hypoxemic respiratory failure, which is likely secondary to a complication of his underlying heart failure. Other potential complications that could arise include worsening of chronic kidney disease, exacerbation of peripheral vascular disease, and further deterioration in mental status.

The patient's current medical management includes mechanical ventilation, diuresis for fluid overload, and insulin therapy for hyperglycemia. The patient is also on prophylactic medications such as SC heparin for deep vein thrombosis prevention, ranitidine for stress ulcer prophylaxis, and ciprofloxacin for ventilator-associated pneumonia prevention.

The patient's recent lab results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate levels, and troponin T, indicating possible ongoing myocardial injury and systemic inflammation. The patient's kidney function remains impaired with elevated creatinine levels. Additionally, the patient has hypernatremia, likely due to free water deficit exacerbated by mechanical ventilation.

Further evaluation and management should focus on weaning off sedation and assessing neurological status, optimizing heart failure management including diuresis and afterload reduction, monitoring and treating renal function, managing diabetes mellitus, and ensuring adequate nutrition. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, oxygenation, and

   Mr [**Known lastname 12627**] suffers from acute resp failure which seems in part due to

   H20 to Rx hypernatremia.  The goals today are to make I/0 2 liters neg,

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, presenting with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure. He also has renal failure, hypernatremia, and altered mental status. The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute hypoxemic respiratory failure may worsen if not properly managed. This can lead to further deterioration in oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Heart failure exacerbation: The patient's chronic systolic heart failure may worsen due to fluid overload or inadequate cardiac output. This can result in pulmonary edema, increased dyspnea, and decreased cardiac function.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress if not addressed appropriately. This can lead to further elevation of creatinine and BUN levels, fluid imbalance, electrolyte disturbances, and potential complications like uremia.
4. Hypernatremia: The patient's high sodium levels need to be corrected to prevent dehydration and potential neurological complications.
5. Altered mental status: The patient's obtundation may be due to various factors such as uremia, steroid use, or other underlying conditions. Monitoring and addressing the underlying cause is crucial to improve mental status.
6. Infection: The patient has been treated with antibiotics for a suspected Klebsiella respiratory infection. Continuous monitoring for signs of infection and adjusting treatment accordingly is important.
7.

24-hour events include bronchoscopy, ultrasound of the gallbladder (GB), and changes in antibiotics based on Klebsiella sensitivity. Renal recommendations include maintaining a sodium level of 144, checking urine electrolytes for evidence of diabetes insipidus, and diuresis.

The patient's weight has decreased from 105.5 kg at admission to 104.1 kg currently.

   83M with systolic heart failure, presenting from OSH with acute
   hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP and acute on CKI.
   Course complicated by hypotension.
 HYPOTENSION (SHOCK)  -  Differential includes septic shock,
   cardiogenic.  Less likely hypovolemic.  PE always on the differential.
   Given fever, favor infection leading to demand ischemia.  See below for
   fever eval.  Will continue dopamine given myocardial ischemia.
   - two units PRBCs, IVF boluses for SBP > 110
   - pan culture, start vanc/zosyn empirically, see below
   - will check mixed venous O2 sat to differentiate septic shock vs.
   cardiogenic shock
   > FEVER
 etiology includes VAP, bacteremia from lines; abdominal
   infection, CNS infection less likely
   - will pan-culture, start zosyn/vanc empirically
   - if PICC line looks like source, will remove, re-site
   - treat fever for transfusion
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE, HYPOXEMIC (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**]): The patient
   presented from an OSH with with vent setting of 10 PEEP, 40% Fi02. Last
   p02 of 60 on FiO2, PEEP 10.  Increased FiO2 to 50%.  Differential of
   failure includes CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis e.g. Goodpasture's
   syndrome, VAP, and obstructive lung disease (noted on CT chest from
   OSH).  Patients last PFTs were noted to be consistent with mild to
   moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.  Autoantibodies such as [**Doctor First Name **],
   ANCA were noted to be negative, and are negative on repeat here.  Path
   report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside hospital shows clear RML
   hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Systolic heart failure, as evidence by
   TTE, is likely the primary component.
   - will upload CT from [**2138-12-22**]
   - will increase steroids to pulse dose
   - f/u BAL results, (-) thus far
   - repeat vasculitis serologies are negative
   - Klebsiella resistant only to amp, will cont cipro today day [**3-15**]
   - see below for CHF management
   - attempt to obtain path slide for additional review
 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
 evidence of
   worsening ischemia laterally in I, aVL and worsening CK, troponin
   elevation.  Cont ASA, defer anticoagulation given recent pulmonary
   hemorrhage and uremia.

 HEART FAILURE (CHF), SYSTOLIC, [**Name (NI) 12685**] Pt with last known EF of 40%.

   overload. Now appears to be clinically hypervolemic  Concern for

   intrinsic. Although now with signs of fluid overload, BUN of 200.

   MICU ATTENDING ADDENDUM
   On this day I examined Mr [**Known lastname 12627**], and reviewed his historical, lab, and
   imaging data. I was present for the key portions of the services
   provided and also have spoken at some length with the patient
s son,
   [**Name (NI) 453**].  I have read Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 9827**]
s note above and agree with his
   findings and plan of care.  There are several issues active in this
   gentleman with multiorgan system failure
   1)       Cardiac
 there is new hypotension and lateral EKG changes and
   a further increase in troponin in this man with known CAD and CHF and
   EF of 35%.  We will give ASA and transfuse to increase 02 delivery to
   heart.  For now BP is being supported with Dopamine.
   2)       Hypotension
 his BP has dropped, as above, and he
s developed
   a fever. It
s not totally clear if this is cardiac or septic, but in
   any case he has lactic acidosis.  The pt has been cultured up and Zosyn
   and Vanc started pending culture results. Steroids also increased to
   stress levels.
   3)       Renal Failure -  pt is in frank renal failure with oliguria,
   BUN of 173 and Cr increased to 2.3, along with hyperkalemia and
   acidosis.  Hemodialysis will commense today.
   4)       Coma
 Exact cause of abnl mentation still not clear, with now
   hypotension added to possible causes. I am still suspicious that uremia
   is contributing to his obtundation and CNS infection seems much less
   likely. TTP has been mentioned (thrombocytopenia, fever, renal failure,
   etc) and we
ll check his rbc smear
   5)       Thrombocytopenia
 plt ct now down to 64k. Ranitidine
   stopped.  Will follow closely
   6)       Resp Failure
 his CxR is largely unchanged and vent settings
   and ABG
s also adequate. Pt may have some central hyperventilation
   (7.50/33/63 on 50%).  His CT from [**State 395**] from [**12-22**] has been found and
   uploaded. It shows multifocal ground glass opacities and tiny right
   pleural effusion.  This pattern is non specific (alv hemorrhage,
   nonbacterial infection, pulm edema, etc) and not particularly
   suggestive of idiopathic BOOP.
   I have explained to the pt
s son that Mr [**Name (NI) 12627**] is very ill with
   multisystem organ failure. We will continue to do our best to dx and rx
   all problems, but the son states that the patient would want all this
   care only so long as we think there is a reasonable chance of his
   returning to his independent lifestyle.
   60 min spent in the care of this critically ill patient.
   [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1620**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1621**], MD

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure presenting from an outside hospital with acute hypoemic respiratory failure and evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP). The patient's course has been complicated by hypotension, fever, and worsening renal function. The patient is currently intubated and sedated, unable to provide a history. He has a known diagnosis of coronary artery disease and has shown signs of worsening ischemia with ST depression in leads I and aVL. The patient's cardiac function has declined, and there is concern for possible cardiogenic shock. Additionally, the patient has acute renal failure, hyperkalemia, and anemia. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiac Complications: The patient's known history of coronary artery disease and worsening ischemia may lead to further cardiac complications such as myocardial infarction or heart failure.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's acute hypoemic respiratory failure and evidence of BOOP may progress to severe respiratory distress requiring mechanical ventilation support.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's worsening renal function and hyperkalemia indicate ongoing renal dysfunction, which may require emergent hemodialysis.
4. Infection: The patient's fever and positive blood cultures suggest the possibility of an ongoing infection, which could be contributing to septic shock.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's low platelet count may increase the risk

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with systolic heart failure who presented to the hospital with acute hypoemic respiratory failure and evidence of BOOP (Bronchiolitis Obliterate Organizing Pneumonia) and acute on CKD (Chronic Kidney Disease). The patient's course has been complicated by hypotension, which may be due to septic shock or cardiogenic shock. Other complications include fever, respiratory failure, coronary artery disease, heart failure, renal failure, anemia, hypernatremia, diabetes mellitus, peripheral vascular disease, and altered mental status.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Septic Shock: The patient's hypotension and fever could indicate septic shock, which is a life-threatening condition that occurs when an infection leads to dangerously low blood pressure.
2. Cardiogenic Shock: Another possibility for the patient's hypotension is cardiogenic shock, which occurs when the heart is unable to pump enough blood to meet the body's needs.
3. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's acute respiratory failure could progress to ARDS, a severe form of lung injury characterized by widespread inflammation in the lungs.
4. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): Given the patient's immobilization and risk factors, a PE should always be considered on the differential diagnosis.
5. Worsening Ischemia: The worsening ST depression in leads I and aVL, along with the elevated cardiac enzymes, suggest

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, presenting from an outside hospital with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure. He has evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) and acute on chronic kidney injury. The patient's last known ejection fraction was 40%. He has a history of coronary artery disease with angioplasty and stenting, chronic kidney disease, diabetes mellitus type II, peripheral vascular disease, and altered mental status. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been sedated. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension (shock) - differential includes septic shock, cardiogenic. Less likely hypovolemic.
2. Fever - etiology includes ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), bacteremia from lines; abdominal infection, CNS infection less likely.
3. Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS) - likely secondary to BOOP and acute on chronic kidney injury.
4. Coronary artery disease (CAD) with ischemic heart disease.
5. Heart failure (CHF), systolic, chronic.
6. Renal failure, acute (acute renal failure, ARF).
7. Hyperkalemia.
8. Anemia.
9. Hypernatremia (high sodium).
10. Diabetes mellitus (DM), type II.
11. Peripheral vascular disease without critical limb ischemia.
12. Altered mental status (not delirium).

Please note that this summary is based on the provided information and may not be exhaustive.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 37-year-old male admitted to the ICU with multiple comorbidities including coronary artery disease (CAD), chronic heart failure (CHF), type II diabetes mellitus (DM), peripheral vascular disease (PVD), and renal failure. The patient presented with altered mental status, respiratory failure, and hypotension. Initial assessment revealed signs of wakefulness but the patient was not following commands. Free water deficit was corrected by administering free water boluses and discontinuing lasix. Sodium levels were corrected and free water boluses were decreased, with the restart of lasix. The patient experienced hypotension overnight, and the transition from levo to dopa was made. 

Key Findings:
- EKG showed worsening ST depression in leads I and aVL.
- Blood cultures were obtained.
- Bronchoalveolar lavage gram stain revealed 1+ polymorphonuclear leukocytes but no microorganisms seen.
- Respiratory culture showed no growth.
- Immunofluorescent test for Pneumocystis jirovecii was negative.
- Viral culture is pending for cytomegalovirus.
- Various laboratory values indicate abnormalities such as elevated white blood cell count, low hematocrit, elevated platelet count, elevated creatinine levels, elevated troponin T level, elevated glucose levels, and abnormal liver function tests.
- Chest X-ray showed diffuse bilateral infiltrates consistent with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

   Assessment and Plan
   83M with systolic heart failure, presenting from OSH with acute
   hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP and acute on CKI.
   Course complicated by hypotension.
 ? Cardiogenic SHOCK  -  Persistently low central venous oxygen
   saturation certainly suggests low cardiac output.   Cardiac enzymes are
   rather confusing, however the fact that the troponins have peaked
   before the CKs, and that the MB fraction is essentially negative likely
   suggests a past cardiac event of uncertain age given ARF, with current
   muscular hypoperfusion in the setting of known PVD.  Given fever,
   infection vs. anemia leading to demand ischemia in past is most likely
   scenario.  See below for fever eval.  Would continue dopamine given
   myocardial ischemia.  Will not start heparin as ischemia likely demand
   and would likely be exacerbated by bleeding.
   - Transfuse to HCT>30
   - Continue Dopamine
   - Trend lactate, Cardiac Enzymes, CVO2
   - ?vigileo to assess stroke volume
   - pan culture, start vanc/zosyn empirically, see below
   .
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)  Patient has not been
   alert/interactive since transfer.  Currently off sedation, would await
   correction of uremia before undertaking any more invasive diagnostic
   endeavors.
   - will attempt daily awakenings, hold sedation
   .
   GI Bleed
 likely upper given coffee grounds and melena clinically.  GI
   has been consulted but I doubt they would scope him in his current
   condition.  Bright red blood has never been expressed on NG lavage.
   - GI RECS
   - DDAVP to address oozing
   - 2 units platelets
   .
   > ANEMIA/thrombocytopenia
 no evidence of hemolysis.  Pt does have
   progressive thrombocytopenia with uremic platelets.  Bumped
   appropriately to 4 units.  While no evidence of hemolysis on smear or
   labs, patient has thrombocytopenia, fever, altered mental status, and
   renal faillure.  Still unlikely to be TTP.
   -Transfuse for HCT>30, PLT>50 given GI bleeding
   - Ferritin elevated, inconsistent with iron deficiency anemia
   .
   > FEVER
 etiology includes VAP, bacteremia from lines; abdominal
   infection, CNS infection less likely
   - will pan-culture, start zosyn/vanc empirically
   - if PICC line looks like source, will remove, re-site
   - treat fever for transfusion
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE, HYPOXEMIC (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**]): The patient
   presented from an OSH with with vent setting of 10 PEEP, 40% Fi02. Last
   p02 of 60 on FiO2, PEEP 10.  Increased FiO2 to 50%.  Differential of
   failure includes CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis e.g. Goodpasture's
   syndrome, VAP, and obstructive lung disease (noted on CT chest from
   OSH).  Patients last PFTs were noted to be consistent with mild to
   moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.  Autoantibodies such as [**Doctor First Name **],
   ANCA were noted to be negative, and are negative on repeat here.  Path
   report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside hospital shows clear RML
   hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Systolic heart failure, as evidence by
   TTE, is likely the primary component.
   - will upload CT from [**2138-12-22**]
   - steroids increased to pulse dose
   - f/u BAL results, (-) thus far
   - repeat vasculitis serologies are negative
   - Klebsiella resistant only to amp, will cont cipro today day [**4-15**]
   - attempt to obtain path slide for additional review
   - wean vent
 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
 evidence of
   worsening ischemia laterally in I, aVL and worsening CK, troponin
   elevation.  Cont ASA, defer anticoagulation given recent pulmonary
   hemorrhage and uremia.  EKG looked closer to baseline.
   -  transfuse goal Hct > 30
   - cont dopamine
   - cont ASA
   .
 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)  DDx includes
   prerenal azotemia (poor forward flow, intravascular depletion),
   intrinsic. Although now with signs of fluid overload, BUN of 200.
   Steroid-induced catabolic state combined with GI bleed likely etiology
   of elevated BUN.  Creatinine and urine output worsening in setting of
   hypotension and possible cardiogenic vs. septic shock.  Hyperkalemia
   progressing.
   - Continue CVVH
   .
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
 had to restart insulin drip
   .
   ..
   FEN: hold TF/ repletion re: CVVH protocol
   .
   PPX:
   -DVT ppx with pneumoboots, pantoprazole
   -Bowel regimen
   -Pain management
   .
   ACCESS: PIV, right PICC, left a-line
   .
   Full Code
   .

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a complex medical history. He presented with acute hypoemic respiratory failure and evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) and acute on chronic kidney injury (CKI). The patient's condition is complicated by cardiogenic shock, hypotension, and fever.

The patient has been diagnosed with several medical conditions, including systolic heart failure, respiratory failure, anemia, thrombocytopenia, fever, and acute renal failure. There is also a mention of coronary artery disease (CAD) with evidence of worsening ischemia and CK/Troponin elevation.

The patient's current medications include dopamine, pantoprazole, heparin sodium (prophylaxis), and other ICU medications. The patient's vital signs are as follows:
- Temperature: 38.3°C (101°F)
- Blood Pressure: 152/78 mmHg
- Heart Rate: 98 bpm
- Respiratory Rate: 32 breaths per minute
- Oxygen Saturation: 100% on supplemental oxygen

The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin, elevated troponin levels, and abnormal liver function tests. Imaging studies show evidence of clear right middle lobe hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.

The patient's plan of care includes transfusion to maintain a hemoglobin concentration above 30 g/dL and platelet count above

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure, presenting from the outside hospital with acute hypoemic respiratory failure and evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP). The patient has also shown signs of acute kidney injury, anemia, thrombocytopenia, fever, and gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's cardiac enzymes are confusing, but it appears to be a past cardiac event of uncertain age. There is evidence of myocardial ischemia and known peripheral vascular disease. The patient's condition has been complicated by hypotension and septic shock.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's low central venous oxygen saturation suggests low cardiac output, indicating cardiogenic shock. This is supported by the presence of systolic heart failure and myocardial ischemia.

2. Acute Respiratory Failure: The patient presented with acute hypoemic respiratory failure and evidence of BOOP. There are several differential diagnoses for respiratory failure, including CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and obstructive lung disease. However, the most likely cause appears to be systolic heart failure, as evidenced by the transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE).

   On this day I examined Mr [**Known lastname 12627**] and reviewed the events of the last

   portions of the services provided and have read Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 11097**]
s note
   above.  I agree with his findings and plan of care.
   As noted in my note from [**1-25**], the pt remains very critically ill with
   multiorgan system failure, including resp failure, renal failure, coma,
   UGI bleeding, hypotension, and cardiac ischemia.  We are continuing
   aggressive medical interventions, including:
   1)       resp failure: continuing mech vent support, now with A/C with
   increased VT to help with air hunger. He
s now been ventilated for
   approx 3 wks. No evidence of new resp infection
   2)       GI bleed: now on IV PPI and has gotten plts and DDAVP. Heparin
   for cardiac status has been avoided, given his bleeding.  GI aware of
   pt but would not EGD unless evidence of ongoing bleeding. In retrospect
   his GI bleeding may have been contributing to rising BUN.
   3)       Hypotension: likely due to cardiac ischemia, poor LVEF, and GI
   bleed in the setting of continuous HD. Actually his dopamine
   requirement is lower today and SBP 120, and perhaps we can wean Dopa
   off.
   4)       Anemia: got 4 units rbc yesterday and will continue to support
   for Hct less than 30.
   5)       Thrombocytopenia: Unclear why plts are so low. Stopped
   ranitidine yesterday. He
s not been on heparin. Will support for plts
   under 50k
   6)       Renal failure: Getting continuous CVVHD and BUN decreasing,
   HCO stable, but so far no improvement in mental status
   7)       Fever, leukocytosis: WBC up to 33k from 24k of past few days.
   Being covered broadly with zosyn and vanc pending culture results
   8)       Unresponsiveness: This is a crucial issue to family.  Dialysis
   ongoing to see if any improvement in mentation as BUN gets below 90 and
   SBP remains over 100. CT just last week showed no cause for current
   obtundation.  If other organ systems improve and mentation doesn
   further neuro assessment may be in order.
   9)       Family communication and pt wishes: I
ve spoken to son [**Name (NI) 453**]
   and daughter [**Name (NI) 4097**] at some length and have explained the gravity of
   Mr [**Known lastname 12627**]
 current multiorgan system failure predicament. I have asked
   them to consider DNR status, given the lack of likely effectiveness of
   CPR in this settting. They will discuss this and get back to team. I
   also told them that this is a very unstable situation and that unless
   several things improve quickly, such as in the next couple of days, I
   didn
t see how Mr [**Known lastname 12627**] could survive all these insults, especially

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with systolic heart failure, presenting from an outside hospital with acute hypoemic respiratory failure and evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) and acute on chronic kidney injury. The patient's course has been complicated by hypotension.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Cardiogenic shock - Persistently low central venous oxygen saturation suggests low cardiac output. Cardiac enzymes are confusing, but the fact that troponins have peaked before the CKs, and the MB fraction is essentially negative likely suggests a past cardiac event of uncertain age given ARF, with current muscular hypoperfusion. PE always on the differential. Given fever, favor infection leading to demand ischemia. Will continue dopamine given myocardial ischemia.
2. GI bleed - likely upper given coffee grounds and melena clinically. GI has been consulted but I doubt they would scope him in his current condition. Bright red blood has never been expressed on NG lavage.
3. Anemia - no evidence of hemolysis. Pt does have progressive thrombocytopenia with uremic platelets. 2 units of PRBCs as above. Consider non-con CT torso if inappropriate bump.
4. Fever - etiology includes VAP, bacteremia from lines; abdominal infection, CNS infection less likely. Will pan-culture, start zosyn/vanc empirically. If PICC line looks like source, will remove, re-site.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with systolic heart failure who presented with acute hypoemic respiratory failure, evidence of BOOP (bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia), and acute on CKI (chronic kidney injury). The patient's course has been complicated by hypotension, GI bleeding, and multiorgan failure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient has low central venous oxygen saturation, suggesting inadequate cardiac output. Imaging suggests CHF (congestive heart failure), and Vigeleo readings indicate normal to high SV (stroke volume) and CO (cardiac output). The patient also has a history of demand ischemia, fever, and anemia, making thrombosis less likely. Heparin is contraindicated due to GI bleed. 

2. Respiratory Failure, Acute, Hypoxemic: The patient presented with a vent setting of 10 PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure) and 40% FiO2 (fraction of inspired oxygen). Differential diagnosis includes CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis (e.g., Goodpasture's syndrome), VAP (ventilator-associated pneumonia), and obstructive lung disease. Imaging from outside hospital shows clear RML (right middle lobe) hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy. The current process is multifactorial, including pulmonary hematoma, CHF, VAP, and underlying COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease).

3. GI Bleed: The patient has a likely upper GI bleed, evidenced by coffee grounds in the orogastric tube. Hct (hematocrit) has only increased by 1 point after 1 U (unit) of PRBCs (packed red blood cells). 

4. Anemia/Thrombocytopenia: The patient has progressive thrombocytopenia with uremic platelets and appears to have a consumptive process since losing transfused plts (platelets) rapidly. PT and PTT (partial thromboplastin time) are prolonged, but fibrinogen levels are normal. There is suspicion of low-level DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation).

5. Bacteremia: Blood culture from [**1-25**] (off A-line) is growing gram-positive cocci in clusters, which is concerning for line source. The patient is afebrile, and WBC (white blood cell) count is trending down. Will monitor with current lines in place given suspicion for contamination rather than infection.

6. Coronary Artery Disease (CAD/Ischemic Heart Disease): There is evidence of worsening ischemia laterally in I, aVL, and worsening CK (creatine kinase), troponin elevation. The patient is not anticoagulated, holding ASA (aspirin), due to GI bleed.

7. Renal Failure, Acute (ARF):

The patient also has altered mental status, hypotension, and gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's condition is complicated by cardiogenic shock, acute renal failure, hypernatremia, diabetes mellitus type II, peripheral vascular disease, and altered mental status.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.9 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 83 beats per minute, blood pressure of 154/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on supplemental oxygen. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 530-680 mL, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 8 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%.

   Assessment and Plan
   83 yom initially respiratory distress/diffuse infilutrates, now with
   multisystem organ failure (respiratory failure, renal failure,
   persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and now GI bleed).  We
   are continuing aggressive medical interventions, including:
   RESPRIATORY FAILURE -- limited progress.  Unclear etiology for
   infiltrates (diffuse, scattered, bilateral).  Development of renal
   failure suggest pulmonary-renal syndrome (anti-GBM syndrome, Wegener's,
   HUS).  Now multifactorial (including diffuse pulmonary disease, CAD,
   CHF, underlying COPD).  Continue steroids, antimicrobials, and
   mechanical ventilation.  Need to consider tracheostomy if no contined
   progress, but family considering long-term options (may not desire
   tracheotomy).
   BACTEREMIA -- GPC in blood culture, likley line-related (PICC, a-line,
   dialysis catheter).  [**Month (only) 51**] need to d/c intravascular catheters.  Plan

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male who was initially admitted with respiratory distress and diffuse infiltrates. He now presents with multisystem organ failure, including respiratory failure, renal failure, persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient's vital signs indicate a heart rate of 84 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 160/42 to 163/63 mmHg, respiratory rate between 24-35 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume set at 530-600 mL, respiratory rate set at 20, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) at 8 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) at 50%.

The patient's physical examination reveals right lower extremity edema, warm skin without rash or jaundice, and neurologic examination showing sedation but purposeful movements. His laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (26.7 K/uL), hemoglobin (10.4 g/dL), creatinine (2.0 mg/dL), and lactate (2.2 mmol/L). The patient also has thrombocytopenia (platelet count of 77), elevated troponin T (0.89 ng/mL), and elevated liver enzymes (ALT/AST 3436/1633).

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old male who was initially experiencing respiratory distress and diffuse infiltrates. He now presents with multisystem organ failure, including respiratory failure, renal failure, persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient has been receiving aggressive medical interventions, including steroids, antimicrobials, and mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has limited progress in respiratory failure, with unclear etiology for infiltrates. This suggests the possibility of pulmonary-renal syndrome (anti-GBM syndrome, Wegener's, HUS). There are also other factors contributing to respiratory failure, such as diffuse pulmonary disease, coronary artery disease (CAD), congestive heart failure (CHF), and underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

2. Bacteremia: GPC in blood culture, likely line-related (PICC, a-line, dialysis catheter). The plan is to continue antimicrobials (Vanco, Zosyn).

3. Fever: Now attributed in part to bacteremia. Monitor fever.

4. Hypotension: Attributed in part to sepsis and in part to acute blood loss, perhaps component of adrenal insufficiency. Currently improved.

5. CAD: Now evidence for myocardial damage --> possible demand ischemia. Monitor serial cardiac meds. Plan check cardiac echo.

6. Melena/Hematochezia: Unc

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure presenting with acute hypoemic respiratory failure, evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP), and acute on chronic kidney injury (CKI). The patient's course has been complicated by hypotension, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome.

The potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Altered Mental Status: The patient has shown signs of opening his eyes to his name, indicating a possible change in mental status. This could be due to poor hepatic clearance of sedatives, delirium, or uremia.

2. GI Bleeding: The patient continues to have blood streaked melena, suggesting ongoing GI bleeding. It is important to continue transfusing the patient and administering DDAVP and platelets to manage the bleeding.

3. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient initially presented with cardiogenic shock, which appeared to be resolved. However, the persistently low central venous oxygen saturation suggests inadequate cardiac output. The patient's ejection fraction is 30-35%, and there is evidence of biventricular dysfunction. It is important to maintain a good mean arterial pressure (MAP) and optimize cardiac output.

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male who was admitted with respiratory distress and diffuse infiltrates. He has now developed multisystem organ failure, including respiratory failure, renal failure, persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient's condition remains critical, and he is being managed with aggressive medical interventions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has diffuse infiltrates and limited progress in respiratory function. There is a concern for pulmonary-renal syndrome, such as anti-GBM syndrome, Wegener's, or HUS. Multifactorial causes like diffuse pulmonary disease, CAD, CHF, and underlying COPD should also be considered. Continuing steroids, antimicrobials, and mechanical ventilation is planned. A tracheostomy may be considered if there is no continued progress.

2. Coma: The patient remains in a persistent coma, which could be attributed to possible anoxic brain injury, uremia, and medications. An evaluation has been unrevealing to date (head CT), and an EEG and possible head MRI are pending. 

3. Bacteremia: The patient has GPC in blood culture, likely line-related. It is planned to continue antimicrobials (Vanco, Zosyn) and remove intravascular catheters. 

4. Fever: The patient's fever is now attributed in part to bacteremia. Monitoring temperature is important.

5. Hypotension:

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male who initially presented with respiratory distress and diffuse infiltrates. He now has multisystem organ failure, including respiratory failure, renal failure, persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient is on aggressive medical interventions, including mechanical ventilation, steroids, antimicrobials, and hemodialysis.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this case include:
1. Pulmonary-renal syndrome (anti-GBM syndrome, Wegener's, HUS): The development of renal failure suggests the possibility of pulmonary-renal syndrome. This condition involves inflammation of both the lungs and kidneys and can be life-threatening if not treated promptly.
2. Diffuse pulmonary disease: The patient's diffuse infiltrates on imaging may indicate a widespread lung condition such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). These conditions can compromise oxygenation and ventilation, leading to further respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient has evidence of myocardial damage, which may suggest ischemic heart disease or a heart attack. This increases the risk of arrhythmias, heart failure, and other cardiac complications.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The presence of melena and hematochezia indicates bleeding in the gastrointestinal tract. This could be due to peptic ulcer disease, gastritis, or other causes. If not identified and managed promptly, it can lead to significant blood loss and hemodynamic instability.
5. Infection-related complications: The patient

- The patient has several medical complications, including bacteremia, acute thrombocytopenia, upper gastrointestinal bleed, acute respiratory failure, chronic heart failure, acute renal failure, hypernatremia, type II diabetes mellitus, peripheral vascular disease, and altered mental status.

1. Infection: The patient has bacteremia, indicating a possible infection in the bloodstream.
2. Bleeding: The patient has upper gastrointestinal bleeding and other gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to significant blood loss and complications.
3. Respiratory issues: The patient has acute respiratory failure, which may require further interventions to maintain adequate oxygenation and ventilation.
4. Cardiac problems: The patient has chronic heart failure and ischemic heart disease, which can result in decreased cardiac output and complications such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.
5. Renal issues: The patient has acute renal failure, which can lead to fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and the need for dialysis.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient's high sodium levels can cause neurological symptoms and complications if not managed properly.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 83-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. He remains intubated and mechanically ventilated. The patient appears more awake and attentive, but still sedated and unable to provide history. The patient has a history of diffuse infiltrates, multisystem organ failure, persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and now gastrointestinal bleeding. The etiology for the infiltrates is unclear, but could be due to pulmonary-renal syndrome or other factors such as CAD, CHF, and underlying COPD. The patient's coma is attributed to uremia, slow clearance of sedating medications, and possible anoxic brain injury. There is a likelihood of line-related bacteremia and an unclear source of melena/haematemesis. The patient has hypotension, renal failure, anemia, hyperglycemia, thrombocytopenia, and liver function abnormalities. The patient's disposition is DNR (do not resuscitate) and is currently in the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has ongoing respiratory distress with diffuse infiltrates and is currently on mechanical ventilation. This indicates a severe lung condition that may lead to further deterioration in respiratory function.
2. Multisystem Organ Failure: The patient has evidence of failure in multiple organ systems including the kidneys, heart, liver, and gastrointestinal system. This increases the risk of further organ dysfunction and failure.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male who was initially admitted with respiratory distress and diffuse infiltrates. The patient now presents with multisystem organ failure, including respiratory failure, renal failure, persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the given information are:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains critical, with limited progress despite aggressive medical interventions. There is an unclear etiology for the infiltrates, and the development of renal failure suggests pulmonary-renal syndrome or other underlying conditions such as anti-GBM syndrome, Wegener's granulomatosis, or HUS. Multifactorial causes including diffuse pulmonary disease, coronary artery disease (CAD), congestive heart failure (CHF), and underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) have been considered.

2. Coma: The patient demonstrates gradual improvement in consciousness, attributed to uremia, slow clearance of sedating medications, and possible anoxic brain injury. Further evaluation with EEG and head MRI or LP may be considered to determine the cause of the coma.

3. Bacteremia: The patient has GPC in the blood culture, likely line-related. The plan is to continue antimicrobials to full course, and the problematic line has been discontinued.

4. Fever: The fever is attributed in part to bacteremia and will be monitored.

5. Hypotension: The patient

The patient's course has been complicated by hypotension, gastrointestinal bleeding, and thrombocytopenia. 

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the information provided in the progress note include:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient presented with acute hypoemic respiratory failure and evidence of BOOP. There is also a mention of potential pulmonary hematoma, congestive heart failure (CHF), ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
2. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has had coffee grounds emesis and melena, suggesting upper gastrointestinal bleeding. There is a mention of a possible consumptive process leading to thrombocytopenia.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has progressive thrombocytopenia with uremic platelets and appears to have a consumptive process. The platelet count is rapidly decreasing despite transfusion, indicating ongoing platelet consumption.
4. Coronary artery disease (CAD): The patient has evidence of worsening ischemia and elevated cardiac enzymes, suggesting myocardial infarction or ischemic heart disease.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 83-year-old male with a complex medical history presenting with acute hypoxic respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and altered mental status. The patient's condition has been complicated by several medical complications including bacteremia, thrombocytopenia, gastrointestinal bleeding, hypotension, coronary artery disease, heart failure, and acute renal failure.

The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, involving pulmonary hematoma, congestive heart failure, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient's mental status has improved gradually, and the cause of altered mental status is likely due to poor hepatic clearance of sedatives and uremia.

The patient has experienced thrombocytopenia with uremic platelets and a consumptive process, possibly related to GI bleeding. The cause of the thrombocytopenia may be pantoprazole or another medication.

The patient's hypotension was initially due to inadequate cardiac output but resolved after optimizing fluid management and cardiac support. The patient has evidence of worsening ischemia and an elevated troponin level, indicating ongoing myocardial ischemia.

The patient has acute renal failure, and the differential diagnosis includes prerenal azotemia, intrinsic renal failure, and postrenal obstruction. The patient is on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH).

The patient's current medical conditions include hypoxic respiratory failure, acute renal failure, altered mental status, and various other complications such as bacteremia, thrombocytopenia, gastrointestinal bleed, coronary artery disease, heart failure, and liver dysfunction. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, receiving supplemental oxygen. They are also receiving CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemofiltration) due to acute renal failure. The patient has a history of chronic conditions like COPD and coronary artery disease. 

The potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, further deterioration of renal function, progression of coronary artery disease, and ongoing hepatic dysfunction. The patient's altered mental status may be due to uremia and hepatic clearance of sedatives. The patient is also at risk for infections such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and bloodstream infections. Thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to increased bleeding risk. The patient's heart failure may progress, and there is a risk of developing cardiogenic shock. Additionally, the patient may develop further complications related to their multiorgan dysfunction syndrome.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of their respiratory, renal, cardiac, and hepatic functions. Based on the provided progress note, the patient's medical complications can be summarized as follows:

1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient presented with acute hypoemic respiratory failure, which is characterized by low oxygen levels in the blood despite adequate ventilation. This condition is likely multifactorial, involving pulmonary hematoma, congestive heart failure (CHF), ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with ground glass opacities of unknown etiology.

2. Acute renal failure: The patient has elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels and is on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH). The cause of acute renal failure includes prerenal azotemia, intrinsic renal damage, and potential ischemic injury to the kidneys.

3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has experienced progressive thrombocytopenia with uremic platelets and a consumptive process. This could be due to pantoprazole therapy or a disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) process. Further evaluation is needed, including HIT and serotonin assays.

4. Coronary artery disease (CAD): There is evidence of worsening ischemia in leads I and aVL, as well as elevated cardiac markers (CK, troponin). The patient is not a candidate for statin therapy at this time due to shock liver and is not anticoagulated due to the risk of gastrointestinal

   83M with systolic heart failure, presenting from OSH with acute
   hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP and acute on CKI,
   altered mental status.  Course complicated by hypotension, GI bleeding.
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia
progressive thrombocytopenia with uremic
   platelets, and appears to have consumptive process since losing
   transfused plts rapidly. PT and PTT now normalized. Fibrinogen nl.
   Pantoprazole could be etiology.
   - transfuse to goal 10, 50 if increased bleeding
   - send HIT and serotonin assay
   - consider holding nonessential meds
   - heme consult, appreciate recs -> ? etiology
   .
   >  GI BLEED
 likely upper given coffee grounds, today coffee grounds
   resolved and residual melena with increased bright red blood overnight.
   - apprecaite GI recs -> ? source/tagged red cell scan?  -> ?
   intervention
   - cont [**Hospital1 7**] pantoprazole
   - cont to transfuse for goal Hct 30, plt 10 if not actively bleeding ->
   gave one bag of plts this A.M. for count of 28 and increased bleeding
   .
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)  Improving very gradually.  We
   will continue off sedation.  Likely [**2-10**] poor hepatic clearance of
   sedatives and uremia causing toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.  Patient
   now answering questions, following commands.  Able to move lower
   extremities, not upper extremities.  MRI shows prior right MCA infarct,
   nothing acute.
   - cont CVVH likely [**1-10**] more days until BUN in 20
   - f/u repeat EEG
   - will D/C meropenem on 1/26f for course of Klebsiella therapy, very
   low suspicion for nosocomial bacterial meningitis
   .
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE, HYPOXEMIC (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**]): The patient
   presented from an OSH with with vent setting of 10 PEEP, 40% Fi02.
   Differential of failure includes CHF, ANCA-associated vasculitis e.g.
   Goodpasture's syndrome, VAP, and obstructive lung disease (noted on CT
   chest from OSH).  Patients last PFTs were noted to be consistent with
   mild to moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.  Autoantibodies such
   as [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA were noted to be negative, and are negative on repeat
   here.  Path report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside hospital shows clear
   RML hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Current process is multifactorial:
   pulmonary hematoma, CHF, VAP and underlying COPD with ground glass
   opacities of unknown etiology.
   - cont PSV trials now that mental status improved
   - follow VBGs and ABGs prn
   - cont to wean steroids, tomorrow methylpred 20 mg IV x 1
   - will need to review OSH CT chest prior to bronch, review path to
   develop differentialy for original presentation of hemopysis -> ? pulm
   edema [**2-10**] heart failure.  Vasculitis, BOOP less likely
   .
 HYPOTENSION- resolved.  Initially, low central venous oxygen
   saturation suggested inadequate cardiac output.  Vigeleo readings
   suggested normal to high SV and CO, thus pt likely requiring higher
   cardiac output than can be achieved without demand . LVEF 30-35% on
   TTE. Pt had recent demand ischemia, in setting of fever and GI bleed
   with anemia, now CE trending down.  Also had complication of shock
   liver.
   - Transfuse to HCT>30  in setting of demand ischemia
   - TTE shows biV dysfunction, no changes, no effusion
   - off Dopamine maintaining good pressures, goal MAP>65
   - cont to trend LFTs, improving

   > BACTEREMIA:

   - surveillance blood cx (-) thus far
   .

   worsening ischemia laterally in I, aVL and worsening CK, troponin
   elevation. Likely demand. Pt not on statin at baseline and not
   candidate for initiation given shock liver. Not anticoagulated, holding

   - will need to restart anti-platelet therapy when GI bleed resolves

   .

   83 yom initially respiratory distress/diffuse infilutrates, now with
   multisystem organ failure (respiratory failure, renal failure,
   persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and now GI bleed).
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE -- limited progress.  Unclear etiology for
   infiltrates (diffuse, scattered, bilateral).  Now multifactorial
   (including diffuse pulmonary disease, CAD, CHF, underlying COPD).
   Continue steroids --> taper, continue antimicrobials, and mechanical
   ventilation.  Need to consider tracheostomy if no continued progress,
   but family considering long-term options (may not desire tracheotomy).

   sedating medications, and possible anoxic brain injury (less likely).

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has been experiencing respiratory distress and diffuse infiltrates, indicating possible pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). These conditions can lead to respiratory failure if not managed properly.

2. Renal Failure: The patient's renal function is compromised, as indicated by elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels. This could be due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) or other factors. Renal failure can further complicate the patient's overall condition and may require dialysis.

3. Persistent Coma: The patient remains in a coma, which may be attributed to uremia, slow clearance of sedating medications, or possible anoxic brain injury. The cause of the coma needs further investigation to determine the appropriate management.

4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, indicating hypotension. This could be due to various factors such as sepsis, cardiac dysfunction, or fluid loss. Hypotension can lead to inadequate organ perfusion and increased risk of complications.

Summary:
The patient is an 83-year-old male who initially presented with respiratory distress and diffuse infiltrates, now with multisystem organ failure (respiratory failure, renal failure, persistent coma, hypotension, cardiac ischemia, and now GI bleed). The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated. Neurologically, the patient continues to demonstrate gradual improvement, particularly in mental status -- more attentive.

The patient has been receiving additional platelet transfusion due to thrombocytopenia. Intermittently requiring insulin drip for hyperglycemia. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.1°C (97°F), heart rate of 86 bpm, blood pressure of 124/73 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on mechanical ventilation.

Physical examination reveals no acute distress, trace right lower extremity edema, and trace left lower extremity edema. The patient's neurologic examination shows that he is attentive, follows simple commands, responds to verbal stimuli, oriented, with purposeful movement of eyes and toes, decreased tone, and generalized diffuse profound weakness.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 7.6 K/uL, hemoglobin of 11.7 g/dL, platelet count of 39 K/uL, blood urea nitrogen of 34 mg/dL, creatinine of 1.0 mg/dL, glucose of 157 mg/dL, sodium of 139 mEq/L, potassium of 4.4 mEq/L, chloride of 104 mEq/L, total bilirubin of 1.9 mg/dL, and liver enzymes (ALT and AST) elevated.

The patient's assessment and plan include ongoing management for respiratory failure, coma, generalized weakness, bacteremia, coronary artery disease, melena/hematochezia, renal failure, anemia, hyperglycemia, thrombocytopenia, liver function abnormalities, and disposition. The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and the disposition is ICU care.

Potential medical complications that can arise include further deterioration of respiratory function, progression of renal failure, worsening of cardiac ischemia, gastrointestinal bleeding, infection due to thrombocytopenia and immunocompromised state, and hepatic dysfunction.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure who presented to the hospital with acute hypoxic respiratory failure and evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) and acute on chronic kidney injury (CKI). The patient's course has been complicated by hypotension, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, thrombocytopenia, altered mental status, respiratory failure, and multiple organ dysfunction.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Continued GI bleeding: The patient has ongoing lower GI bleeding, which may continue to pose a risk for further blood loss and potential hemorrhagic shock.
2. HIT (heparin-induced thrombocytopenia): The patient has tested positive for HIT antibodies, indicating a possible immune response to heparin therapy. This increases the risk of thrombotic events if heparin is not discontinued promptly.
3. Uremic platelets: The patient's chronic kidney injury may lead to uremic platelets, which can contribute to bleeding complications.
4. Hypotension: The patient's history of hypotension suggests the possibility of recurrent low blood pressure episodes, potentially leading to inadequate tissue perfusion and organ dysfunction.
5. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's current treatment with continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) indicates ongoing renal dysfunction, which can predispose to electrolyte imbalances and fluid overload.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 83-year-old male with a history of systolic heart failure. He presented with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure and evidence of bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP) and acute on chronic kidney injury (CKI). The patient's course has been complicated by hypotension, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, thrombocytopenia, altered mental status, and several other medical complications.

The patient's respiratory failure has shown improvement but experienced a decompensation after going to low level pressure support. This decompensation was rapidly recovered without intervention, making pulmonary embolism and right-sided myocardial infarction unlikely. The differential diagnosis for the initial failure includes congestive heart failure (CHF), ANCA-associated vasculitis, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and obstructive lung disease.

The patient also has evidence of a lower GI bleed, which is confirmed by GI department as low volume BRBPR with resolved coffee grounds and melena. The GI department has decided not to scope and will not perform a tagged red cell scan. The patient is being transfused for goal Hct 30, plt 10 if not actively bleeding.

Thrombocytopenia is progressing with uremic platelets and suspected contribution of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). The patient's platelets are being rapidly lost, and PT and PTT are now normalized.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is critically ill with multiple medical complications. The potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing acute dyspnea and requires mechanical ventilation support. There are basilar and mid-lung zone infiltrates seen on chest X-ray, which could indicate pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient also has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation.

2. Coronary Artery Disease (CAD): The patient has marked calcific CAD on imaging, suggesting significant coronary artery disease. This increases the risk of myocardial ischemia or infarction.

3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a low platelet count, which is concerning for thrombocytopenia. A positive PF4 assay indicates the possibility of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), a prothrombotic disorder.

4. Renal Failure: The patient initially presented with very uremic levels on admission but has shown improvement with continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH). There is a plan to attempt a trial off CVVH soon.

5. Gastrointestinal Bleeding (GIB): The patient initially had coffee grounds from the NG tube, suggesting upper GI bleeding. However, there is persistent blood-tinged retching and bradycardia, suggesting possible lower GI bleeding or ongoing upper GI bleeding. Ischemic

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 45-year-old male with a history of chronic heart failure and acute respiratory failure. He presented to the ICU with hypoxia and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient has been on mechanical ventilation since admission and has required multiple interventions including continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), vasopressor support, and blood product transfusions. His laboratory values indicate acute kidney injury, elevated cardiac enzymes, and coagulopathy. The patient also has a history of diabetes mellitus type II.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) puts him at risk for continued respiratory failure. Close monitoring of oxygenation and ventilation parameters is essential.

2. Coronary Artery Disease: The patient has marked calcific coronary artery disease on imaging. There is a risk of recurrent myocardial ischemia or infarction due to compromised coronary blood flow.

3. Thrombocytopenia, Acute: The patient has a positive platelet factor 4 (PF4) test, indicating the possibility of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). This condition can lead to a low platelet count and an increased risk of bleeding or thrombosis.

4. Renal Failure, Acute: The patient's renal function is compromised, as indicated by elevated serum creatinine levels and uremic symptoms. Close monitoring of renal function and continued use of CRRT may be necessary

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient presents with hypoxia and acute respiratory failure. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, thrombocytopenia, acute renal failure, gastrointestinal bleed, hypertension, chronic heart failure, hypernatremia, diabetes mellitus type II, peripheral vascular disease, and altered mental status.

The patient's current vital signs show a heart rate of 90 bpm, blood pressure of 132/64 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 798 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%. The respiratory support indicates the need for careful monitoring and management of the patient's respiratory status.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC), hemoglobin (Hct), and lactate levels, along with elevated cardiac enzymes and liver enzymes. The presence of these abnormalities suggests ongoing systemic inflammation and potential complications such as sepsis or myocardial infarction.

The patient's imaging shows right basilar and mid-lung zone infiltrates on chest X-ray, which may indicate pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The positioning of the endotracheal tube (ETT) is also noted.

The assessment and plan section highlights several potential medical complications that the patient may face

   Assessment and Plan
   83M with systolic heart failure, presenting from OSH with acute
   hypoexmic respiratory failure with evidence of BOOP and acute on CKI,
   altered mental status.  Course complicated by hypotension, GI bleeding.
   .
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE, HYPOXEMIC (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 11**]): Had been
   improving and requiring less and less support, however today after
   going to low level pressure support, after 30 minutes he became
   tachycardic, and tachypneic and required return to ventilatory support
   at CMV.  He also had some evidence of anxiety vs fatigue which is what
   I suspect the etiology of his tachypnea and decompensation was.  He
   rapidly recovered with no intervention making PE and Right sided MI
   unlikely.  X-ray was inconsistent with flash.
   .
    Differential of initial failure includes CHF, ANCA-associated
   vasculitis e.g. Goodpasture's syndrome, VAP, and obstructive lung
   disease (noted on CT chest from OSH).  Patients last PFTs were noted to
   be consistent with mild to moderate restrictive ventilatory defect.
   Autoantibodies such as [**Doctor First Name **], ANCA were noted to be negative, and are
   negative on repeat here.  Path report c/w BOOP.  Imaging from outside
   hospital shows clear RML hemorrhage post-bronchoscopy.  Current process
   is multifactorial: pulmonary hematoma, CHF, VAP and underlying COPD
   with ground glass opacities of unknown etiology.
   - cont PSV trials now that mental status improved
 did well yesterday
   with NIF of -20, RSBI of 53 yesterday
   - follow VBGs and ABGs prn
   - cont to wean steroids, would change to home dose today.
   .
   Pancytopenia
 Stopped meropenem which can cause pancytopenia, would
   continue to trend.
   .
   >  GI BLEED
 GI thinks this is lower, as low volume BRBPR with now
   resolved coffee grounds and melena.
   - GI says they will not scope and will not do tagged red cell scan
   - cont [**Hospital1 7**] pantoprazole
   - cont to transfuse for goal Hct 30, plt 10 if not actively bleeding
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia
progressive thrombocytopenia with uremic
   platelets, with ?contribution of HIT.   Appears to have consumptive
   process since losing transfused plts rapidly. PT and PTT now
   normalized. Fibrinogen nl.  Heparin and vanc stopped.  Pantoprazole
   could be etiology.
   - transfuse to goal 10, 50 if increased bleeding
   - send HIT + and serotonin assay
 pending
   - consider holding nonessential meds
   - Would hold off on anti-coagulation at least until SRA returns
   .
 ALTERED MENTAL STATUS (NOT DELIRIUM)  Improving very gradually.  We
   will continue off sedation.  Likely [**2-10**] poor hepatic clearance of
   sedatives and uremia causing toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.  Patient
   now answering questions, following commands.  Able to move lower
   extremities, not upper extremities.  MRI shows prior right MCA infarct,
   nothing acute.
   - trial off CVVH
   - f/u repeat EEG
   - will D/C meropenem.
   .
 HYPOTENSION- resolved.  Initially, low central venous oxygen
   saturation suggested inadequate cardiac output.  Vigeleo readings
   suggested normal to high SV and CO, thus pt likely requiring higher
   cardiac output than can be achieved without demand . LVEF 30-35% on
   TTE. Pt had recent demand ischemia, in setting of fever and GI bleed
   with anemia, now CE trending down.  Also had complication of shock
   liver.
   - Transfuse to HCT>30  in setting of demand ischemia
   - TTE shows biV dysfunction, no changes, no effusion
   - off Dopamine maintaining good pressures, goal MAP>65
   - cont to trend LFTs, improving
   .
   > WEAKNESS -> likely [**2-10**] steroids, paralysis, prolonged ICU course.
   - Neuro thinks its critical care myopathy with superimposed steroid
   myopathy.
   > BACTEREMIA:
 blood cx from [**1-25**] (off A-line) growing CoNS. A-line
   D/Ced. Off vanco.
   - surveillance blood cx (-) thus far
   .
 CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE (CAD, ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE)
 evidence of
   worsening ischemia laterally in I, aVL and worsening CK, troponin
   elevation. Likely demand. Pt not on statin at baseline and not
   candidate for initiation given shock liver. Not anticoagulated, holding
   ASA, due to GI bleed.
   -  transfuse goal Hct > 30
   - will need to restart anti-platelet therapy when GI bleed resolves
   - recheck ECG this morning
   .
   > BIVENTRICULAR SYSTOLIC HEART FAILURE-  Likely [**2-10**] CAD.  Will need to
   optimize regimen with ACEi, possibly B-blockage (if PR prolongation has
   resolved) once renal failure and GI bleed resolve.  Transfusion goal as
   above.  No pressor support currently needed.
   .
 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)  DDx includes
   prerenal azotemia (poor forward flow, intravascular depletion),
   intrinsic. BUN elevated [**2-10**] GI bleed as well. On CVVH. Hyperkalemia
   persistant on CVVH, likely due to cell destruction and muscle ischemia
   given high CKs.
   - Continue CVVH with goal TBB -1 to 2L today
   - appreciate renal recs
   .

   down
   - monitor daily
   - hold any hepatotoxic or hepatically cleared meds
   .
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
 cont insulin drip
